subject: linear_algebra
title: Systems of Linear Equations
subtitle: Matrix form and solution types
contentHtml:
A system of linear equations is a set of simultaneous equations in which each equation is a linear combination of the variables.

We can represent these systems using matrices, where each row corresponds to an equation and each column represents a variable. The matrix form is Ax=b, where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the vector of variables, and b is the constant vector.
intuition: Understanding systems of linear equations is crucial in many areas, including machine learning. For instance, in neural networks, we often encounter systems of linear equations when computing the output of a layer.
commonMistakes: Forgetting to consider the possibility of multiple solutions

In matrix form, this can be represented as Ax=b, where A is the coefficient matrix, x is the column vector of variables, and b is the constant term vector.
intuition: Think of a system of linear equations as a set of constraints that must be satisfied simultaneously. The matrix form provides a concise way to represent these constraints and solve for the variables.
commonMistakes: Failing to recognize the importance of the coefficient matrix A
Not considering the possibility of multiple solutions or no solution at all

subject: linear_algebra
statementHtml:
Solve the system of linear equations
\[x + 2y - z = 1\]
\[3x - y + 4z = 7\]
\[x - 3y + 2z = -2\] in matrix form.",
hints: Start by writing the augmented matrix A|b
Use row operations to transform A into upper triangular form
The solution is now easily read from the right-hand side
solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we first write it in matrix form:


\[A|b = \begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -1 \\ 3 & -1 & 4 \\ 1 & -3 & 2 \end{bmatrix} | \begin{bmatrix} 1 \\ 7 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}\]

We then apply row operations to transform A into upper triangular form:


\[R_1 \rightarrow R_1 + 3R_2, R_2 \rightarrow R_2 - 9R_1\]
\[\begin{bmatrix} 1 & 2 & -1 \\ 0 & -13 & 11 \\ 1 & -3 & 2 \end{bmatrix} | \begin{bmatrix} 4 \\ 7 \\ -2 \end{bmatrix}\]

The solution is now easily read from the right-hand side:


\[x = 0, y = 1, z = 1\]",

problem.statementHtml: Solve the system of linear equations represented by the matrix equation \[A\mathbf{x} = \mathbf{b}\], where A is a 2x3 matrix and b is a 2-element vector.
hints: Check if any rows or columns of A are zero.
Try to find the free variable(s) in the system.
Use back-substitution to find the value of x.
problem.solutionHtml:
To solve this system, we can use row operations to transform A into upper triangular form.

  • Swap rows 1 and 2: \[\begin{bmatrix}0 & 1 & -2 \ 1 & 0 & 3 \end{bmatrix}\]
  • Eliminate the second row:
    • \[x_1 + 2x_2 = 4\]
    • \[x_2 = 2\]
  • Solve for x_1: \[x_1 = 0\]
